posts.name: Lucas Dankert
posts.cooked:
Over the summer, I had the chance to work a lot with Altair Inspire and I think it is heavily underutilized in the FIRST community and teams. The software is really accessible for teams and it is a very intuitive program to learn and use.

The simplest feature is structural analysis. This feature allows you to view points in a part that might be over engineered or stress points. This allows you to make better and more informed decisions about where you are putting material in the part.

Taking it farther, you can also use the topological optimization feature. This feature will use the data from structural analysis and automatically make decisions about where to reduce or add material. In my experience, this can save 60-70% of the weight of a part while retaining structural stability and rigidity.

The most advanced, but still useful, feature is motion analysis. You can simulate arms, elevators, claws, etc. to make sure that it has your desired range, speed, and interaction with other elements. I used it to simulate my team’s deep climber before we tested it in real life. This allowed us to save material in prototyping and time in testing.

The best part about this software is that it is free to all FRC teams. If you go to the virtual kit of parts and click on the Altair link, it will walk you through how to create a student account and give you video tutorials of how to do everything I’ve talked about.

posts.name: Espino
posts.cooked:
LucasDankert:

Taking it farther, you can also use the topological optimization feature. This feature will use the data from structural analysis and automatically make decisions about where to reduce or add material. In my experience, this can save 60-70% of the weight of a part while retaining structural stability and rigidity.

Hello. Do you know if the topological analysis take more time than SolidWorks or is it faster?

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Given several flags about this content surrounding advertisment (which is allowed when done responsibly) I have temporary closed this thread to discuss with the rest of the moderation team and discuss further action. The thread may reopen.

Given some helpful context from several users around Altair team sponsorships I am going to re-open this thread. Thanks for your patience and to those users for context.

Disclosure of sponsorship or affiliation, in cases like this, are helpful to other users in identifying the nature of the post and how best to engage with the thread.

If you have concerns you are welcome to message the moderators via direct message.

posts.cooked:

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Yeah… Perhaps off topic for this thread, but something for teams to be aware of as they prepare students for the professional world.

As somebody who knows how to use FEA, it is a very powerful tool… if and only if you know what you are doing which the vast majority of FRC students don’t due to the sheer difficulty of FEA. And running FEA is extremely slow which most teams don’t have time for in the build season. If you aren’t familiar with linear algebra, numerical methods, and mechanics of materials, you won’t have sufficient background to understand what FEA is doing well enough to get accurate and correct results which matters because you will run into errors and misleading results and you need to know what you are doing to fix them.

LucasDankert:

The software is really accessible for teams and it is a very intuitive program to learn and use.

Pushing buttons in your favorite FEA software is the easy part and anybody can do that in any FEA software, the hard part is both knowing what buttons you should be pushing and that the FEA is outputting accurate results. That part is an upper-level undergratuate and graduate topics, which are out of reach of nearly every FRC student. All accurate FEA analyses consist of validation models before running the full model, all of which will run into so many errors of multiple flavors. You will run into solutions that won’t converge, pivot errors, and solutions that will solve but with incorrect results. Without sufficient background, these are difficult to impossible to resolve.

When I was taking FEA classes, my prof gave us a report that looked pretty but was wrong in every way imaginable. If we didn’t know how FEA and the math behind it worked, we would’ve missed many of the errors that were shown to us. The point of this exercise was to emphasize just how easy it is to make errors and how hard it is to find them.

FEA is one of the strongest cases of “garbage in garbage out” in the world, where the garbage in can be extremely subtle, sometimes even due to a single bad element leading to errors. Suppose I ask “what are the loading conditions?” For 95% of FRC parts, you can’t know (or even control) this, which makes any FEA you do as a result almost useless. For those, now what about the boudary conditions? You can’t always Saint-Vernant away the boundary conditions and sometimes those are very hard to set up accurately. Of those, most parts that people care about will be under impact which requires you run run explicit analysis which is about the hardest FEA to run into. Oftentimes, points of contact are the points under stress which are annoying to simulate in FEA due to convergence issues. So we are left with simple part under simple loads. For those, basic mechanics of materials formulas like my/I will get you the result you want takes 2 minutes instead of 2 hours.

LucasDankert:

The most advanced, but still useful, feature is motion analysis. You can simulate arms, elevators, claws, etc. to make sure that it has your desired range, speed, and interaction with other elements. I used it to simulate my team’s deep climber before we tested it in real life. This allowed us to save material in prototyping and time in testing.

You can also do this by dragging parts around in cad and then build the dynamic sim in something like simulink or python or just use AMB and get the same results for less effort and time. Simulating all robot parts takes a ton of time as now you are working with contact elements which have convergence issues resulting in a ton of fliddling with analysis and mesh settings to even get a solution to converge.

Short answer, no, FEA packaging including Altair are not underused in FRC , they are just an inherently hard and slow tool to use which doesn’t make them particularly useful in a competition where you only have a 6 week build season. You can get 95% of the benefits faster using hand calcs or dedicated dynamic simulation software and for the other 5%, there’s faster ways to improve your robot than using FEA.

HUGODANIEL09:

Hello. Do you know if the topological analysis take more time than SolidWorks or is it faster?

Solidwork’s FEA tools are really bad and I wouldn’t recommend using them over a proper FEA software. Notable flaws include limited mesh controls (limited control over element size, no refinement options, no hex elements), limited boundary condition support, limited support for non-linear analysis (large deflections, contacts, yielding)…

The speed of your analysis is  strongly a function of how you set up your mesh. Swapping softwares to get more mesh options (like hex elements) may speed up your results, but all FEA software is doing the same math so you won’t get much speed improvements by going to a more “efficient” software.

posts.name: Espino
posts.cooked: I completely agree with your opinion. In FRC , most things can be solved with some napkin math and a basic understanding of how forces behave. I’m more familiar with analysis in SolidWorks due to work-related reasons, and getting good results can be pretty tedious. I wouldn’t want to limit myself to using just one software. I appreciate your thoughts and comments.

HUGODANIEL09:

I’m more familiar with analysis in SolidWorks due to work-related reasons, and getting good results can be pretty tedious.

This is a fact of FEA but better meshers should help. I personally do everything in Ansys due to what my school provides access to, but they do also provide free education licensees. It has a much better mesher than solidworks, but its still pretty finicky and doesn’t like small geometry very well and can misbehave when sweeping. Although I haven’t personally used it, Altair’s own hypermesh is commonly used and is (supposedly) better and then the mesh can be exported to some other solver software.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Hey Lucas! Welcome to CD !

It’s great to hear you had positive experiences with Inspires.

LucasDankert:

I think it is heavily underutilized in the FIRST community and teams.

When talking about adoption of a tool in a broad community, the important question to answer is “Why is this tool better than the alternatives?”.

Your post talks a lot about why Inspires is good , which puts it on the table as an option… but not necessarily as the right option for any particular team.

I’d encourage you to dive in and take that next step: If you believe it’s under-utilized, show how it exceeds the technical and inspirational qualities of other tools. That’s the kind of thing that drives adoption.
